message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of orbital cellulitis, which is a potentially serious infection of the eye and surrounding tissues. The fact that eye movements are restricted and painful in all directions indicates involvement of the extraocular muscles and suggests that the infection is spreading rapidly. Pain with eye movements provides the strongest indication for administering intravenous antibiotics to prevent further spread of the infection to the brain. The other options (worsening of ocular pain, leukocytosis, purulent nasal discharge and right cheek tenderness) are also important indications for antibiotic therapy, but they are not as urgent as pain with eye movements.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the given options, the strongest indication for administering intravenous antibiotics to this patient is pain with eye movements, which suggests orbital cellulitis. Leukocytosis and purulent nasal discharge and right cheek tenderness can also be present in orbital cellulitis, but pain with eye movements is a more specific indicator. Worsening of ocular pain also supports the diagnosis of orbital cellulitis but is not as strong an indication as pain with eye movements.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest orbital cellulitis, which is a serious infection that can lead to vision loss and even death. The strongest indication for administering intravenous antibiotics is pain with eye movements, as this indicates involvement of the extraocular muscles and a potentially severe infection. Leukocytosis and purulent nasal discharge and right cheek tenderness are supportive findings, but not as strong of an indication as pain with eye movements.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The ophthalmic examination, with proptosis, edema, erythema, and restricted and painful eye movements, suggests orbital cellulitis. Pain with eye movements is a sign of a serious condition that may lead to irreversible vision loss and is the strongest indication for administering intravenous antibiotics. While leukocytosis and purulent nasal discharge and right cheek tenderness are also suggestive, they do not indicate the need for urgent intervention as much as pain with eye movements does.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of orbital cellulitis, which is a serious infection that can cause vision loss and even death if left untreated. The strongest indication for administering intravenous antibiotics is the pain with eye movements, as this suggests that the infection has spread to the eye itself and is threatening vision. The other symptoms also support the diagnosis of orbital cellulitis, but do not necessarily indicate the need for immediate administration of antibiotics.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest orbital cellulitis, which can cause optic nerve damage and blindness if not treated promptly. Pain with eye movements is a serious symptom that strongly indicates the need for intravenous antibiotics. Worsening of ocular pain, leukocytosis, and purulent nasal discharge and right cheek tenderness are also indications for treatment, but not as strong as pain with eye movements.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest acute bacterial sinusitis with orbital involvement, including painful eye movements, proptosis, and edema, erythema, and tenderness of the eyelids. Pain with eye movements is a sign of orbital inflammation and provides the strongest indication for administering intravenous antibiotics. Leukocytosis and purulent nasal discharge provide additional support for the diagnosis, but are not as strong of an indication for antibiotic treatment as eye movement pain.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest orbital cellulitis, which is a serious infection. The strongest indication for administering intravenous antibiotics is pain with eye movements, as it suggests involvement of the optic nerve and may lead to vision loss. Worsening of ocular pain, leukocytosis, and purulent nasal discharge and right cheek tenderness are also important factors, but not as strong of an indication as pain with eye movements.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of orbital cellulitis with purulent nasal discharge, cheek tenderness, and proptosis. However, the strongest indication for administering intravenous antibiotics is the pain with eye movements, as this suggests involvement of the extraocular muscles and potential threat to vision. Leukocytosis and purulent nasal discharge are supportive but not the strongest indication for immediate treatment.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest orbital cellulitis, which is a serious condition that requires prompt treatment with antibiotics. Among the options, pain with eye movements is the strongest indication for administering intravenous antibiotics as it suggests involvement of the extraocular muscles and possible optic nerve compression, which can lead to vision loss if left untreated. Leukocytosis and purulent nasal discharge are also suggestive of infection, but they are not specific to orbital cellulitis.
